initial_deck.instructions:
# Instructions

DeckId: FEN_GDH (or DeckKey)
Title: Good Health

## Plan Tiers Overview

GHDP-W - Good Health Wellness Plan
GHDP-1 - Good Health 1 Plan
GHDP-2 - Good Health 2 Plan
GHDP-3 - Good Health 3 Plan
GHDP-4 - Good Health 4 Plan
GHDP-5 - Good Health 5 Plan

**Always include all plans in the summary.**

3.summary:
The GDHP-1 plan offers specific benefits under physician services, telemedicine, and advocacy. For primary care office visits, the plan allows for three visits per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum of $150 per visit. Specialist or urgent care office visits are limited to one visit per year, with a co-pay of $50 and a maximum of $300 per visit. The in-patient hospitalization benefit provides $1,000 per day, with a yearly maximum of $5,000, and includes a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. Telemedicine services are available with no consult fee and no maximum limit. Discount prescriptions are available through participating pharmacies only. The plan also includes advocacy services, such as a hospital bill reducer, to assist with managing healthcare expenses.

The plan emphasizes that all sickness benefits are subject to a 30-day waiting period before they become payable. Outpatient physician services and wellness benefits require in-network providers, while inpatient hospital indemnity benefits do not. The plan is not a major medical plan and is limited to covering preventive and wellness services as required by law. It is important to review the schedule of benefits for detailed coverage information, including copays, deductibles, and limitations.

2.summary:
The GHDP-W plan offers specific benefits focusing on wellness exams and telemedicine services. Under the Physician Services, which utilize the First Health Network, the plan provides one wellness exam per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum charge of $150 per visit. Telemedicine services are available through Recuro Health with no consult fee and no maximum limit on usage. Additionally, the plan includes access to discount prescriptions through BestChoice RX participating pharmacies. 

The plan emphasizes support services through Kindly Human, offering 24/7 assistance for everyday challenges. This service is designed to connect individuals with someone who can relate to their experiences, providing fundamental human support. 

There are specific limitations and requirements associated with the plan. All sickness benefits are subject to a 30-day waiting period before they become payable. Outpatient physician services and wellness benefits are restricted to in-network providers only, while inpatient hospital indemnity benefits are not subject to this restriction. The plan is not a major medical plan and does not cover services unless listed in the Schedule of Benefits. It is limited to preventive and wellness services as required by law, with detailed information on copays, deductibles, and limitations provided in the Summary Plan Description.

1.summary:
The GHDP Summary page outlines the features and benefits of various health plans, including GHW, GH1, GH2, GH3, GH4, and GH5. Key benefits across these plans include Telemedicine, BestChoiceRX Group Discount Program, and BestChoiceRX Plus, which offers non-preferred generic and brand medications with a co-pay up to $150 per month. Preventative care and annual wellness exams are available in most plans, with specific coverage details varying by plan. Specialty drugs and prescription assistance programs are also highlighted.

The page details primary care physician visits, with GH1 covering one visit, GH2 covering two, and GH5 covering up to five visits. Specialist and urgent care visits are similarly tiered, with GH1 covering one visit and GH5 covering five. Hospital indemnity benefits, emergency room services, ambulance services, and in-out patient surgery are included in all plans, with specific conditions and limitations noted.

Dental plans are available with annual maximums of $1,500, $3,000, and $5,000 per person, depending on the plan tier. The Dental/Vision Bundle emphasizes a digital-first platform for vision services, aiming to replace traditional insurance while maintaining cost efficiency and satisfaction.

Limitations include a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits, in-network provider requirements for outpatient services, and exclusions for pre-existing conditions within the first twelve months. The plan is not a major medical plan and does not cover services outside the Schedule of Benefits.

4.summary:
The GHDP-2 plan offers specific benefits for physician services and prescription terms. Under physician services, members are allowed up to four primary care office visits per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum charge of $150 per visit. Specialist or urgent care office visits are limited to two per year, with a co-pay of $50 and a maximum charge of $300 per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits are provided at $1,000 per day, with a yearly maximum of $10,000, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. Telemedicine services are available with no consult fee and no maximum limit. 

For prescriptions, the plan includes preventive and acute prescriptions subject to a formulary, with no monthly maximum. Pharmacy retail for up to a 30-day supply of acute and preventive generic drugs requires the member to pay, while generic drugs have a $0 copay. For a 90-day supply of maintenance drugs, members pay, with preferred generics having a $5 copay. The RX plan includes discounts for formulary prescriptions, but specialty drugs are not covered. Members may qualify for the Prescription Assistance Program based on income guidelines. 

Additional support services include Kindly Human for 24/7 access to support and MyHealthcare Ninja for advocacy. The plan includes a hospital bill reducer. Limitations include a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and restrictions on inpatient hospital indemnity benefits. Pre-existing conditions are not covered for the first 12 months. The plan is not a major medical plan and is limited to preventive and wellness services.

5.summary:
The GHDP-3 plan offers a structured set of benefits focusing on physician services, telemedicine, and prescription coverage. Under physician services, members are entitled to four primary care office visits per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum of $150 per visit. Specialist or urgent care visits are also limited to four per year, with a co-pay of $50 and a maximum of $300 per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits are set at $1,000 per day, with a yearly maximum of $15,000, and a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion applies.

Telemedicine services are provided with no consult fee and no maximum limit, enhancing accessibility to healthcare professionals. Prescription coverage includes preventive and acute prescriptions, with specific terms and conditions. For pharmacy retail up to a 30-day supply, members pay for acute and preventive generic drugs, while generic drugs have a $0 copay. Preferred generic drugs have a $5 copay, and non-preferred generics require member payment with retail copays of $5 and $10, and mail order copays of $5 and $20 for a 90-day supply. Brand drugs require prior authorization, with member payment and retail copays of $40 and mail order copays of $80 for a 90-day supply.

The plan includes prescription terms and conditions, such as a $150 benefit limit per person per month for non-preventive maintenance prescriptions. Specialty drugs are not covered, and members may qualify for a Prescription Assistance Program based on income guidelines. Additional support services include advocacy and hospital bill reduction, with a focus on providing access to support 24/7. Limitations include a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and specific exclusions for pre-existing conditions.

6.summary:
The GDHP-4 plan offers a range of benefits focusing on physician services, telemedicine, and prescription coverage. Under physician services, the plan includes one wellness exam per year with a $25 co-pay and a maximum of $150 per visit. Primary care office visits are covered up to four times a year with a $50 co-pay and a $150 maximum per visit. Specialist or urgent care office visits are also covered up to four times a year with a $75 co-pay and a $300 maximum per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits provide $1,000 per day with a $10,000 yearly maximum, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion. In/outpatient surgery is covered up to $1,000 per year with a $2,000 yearly maximum, also subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion. Emergency room visits, if admitted, have a $1,000 per incident benefit, and ambulance services are covered at $500 per incident, both with a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion.

Telemedicine services are offered with no consult fee and no maximum limit. The plan includes preventive and acute prescription coverage, with member pays for pharmacy retail up to a 30-day supply and mail order up to a 90-day supply. Non-preferred generic drugs have a retail co-pay of $5 and $10, and mail order co-pays of $8 and $20. Brand drugs require prior authorization and have retail co-pays of $30 for 30 days and $80 for 90 days. Prescription terms specify that non-preventive maintenance prescriptions have a $150 benefit limit per person per month, with specialty drugs not covered. The plan also includes advocacy support through Kindly Human and MyHealthcare Ninja, providing hospital bill reduction services.

The plan has specific limitations, including a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and exclusions for out-of-network providers for inpatient hospital indemnity benefits. Pre-existing condition exclusions apply for the first 12 months of coverage, and certain benefits are not payable for pre-existing conditions as defined in the policy.

7.summary:
The GDHP-5 plan offers a range of benefits focusing on physician services, telemedicine, and prescription coverage. Under physician services, the plan includes one wellness exam per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum of $150 per visit. It also covers up to five primary care office visits annually, with a $50 co-pay and a $150 maximum per visit. Specialist or urgent care visits are similarly covered, with a $75 co-pay and a $300 maximum per visit.

In-patient hospitalization benefits are provided at $1,500 per day, with a yearly maximum of $15,000, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. In/outpatient surgery is covered at $1,500 per day, with a $4,500 yearly maximum, also subject to the pre-existing condition clause. Emergency room visits, if admitted, incur a $1,000 per incident charge, and ambulance services are covered at $500 per incident, both with the same pre-existing condition limitations.

Telemedicine services are offered with no consult fee and no maximum limit. Prescription coverage includes preventive and acute prescriptions, with member payments required for retail and mail-order options. Non-preferred generic and brand drugs require member payments, with specific costs outlined for 30-day and 90-day supplies. The plan also includes advocacy support through the Hospital Bill Reducer service.

Limitations include a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and restrictions on non-preventive maintenance prescriptions. Specialty drugs are not covered, and there are specific conditions for pre-existing conditions and network usage.

8.summary:
This document outlines the preventive health services covered under the MEC/Preventive Health Services plan. Benefits are subject to specific regulations and amendments, ensuring compliance with legislative acts. The services covered are based on recommendations from the United States Preventive Services Task Force, focusing on medical services with a rating of 'A' or 'B'. Preventive care and screenings for various age groups, including infants, children, and adolescents, are provided following guidelines from the Health Resources and Services Administration. Immunizations are recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices for certain individuals.

The document includes a detailed table listing various preventive health services, their intervals, and specific requirements. For example, abdominal aortic aneurysm screening is available once per lifetime for men aged 65-75 who have smoked. Adult annual standard physicals are covered once per plan year for adults. Alcohol misuse screening and counseling are provided annually for adults 18 years or older. Aspirin as a preventive medication is prescribed for adults aged 50 to 59 with high cardiovascular risk. Other services include bacteriuria screening for pregnant women, BRCA risk assessment, and breast cancer preventive medications.

It is important to note that none of the preventive health services are covered if provided at a hospital. This limitation is explicitly stated, ensuring clarity on the coverage restrictions.

12.summary:
This page provides a detailed summary of immunization benefits under the MEC/Preventive Health Services plan. It outlines the recommended vaccines for children from birth through eighteen years old, as advised by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The document is divided into two sections based on age groups: Birth Through Six Years Old and Children From Seven Through Eighteen Years Old. 

For children from birth through six years old, the vaccines include Hepatitis B, Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Acellular Pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib), Pneumococcal 13-valent Conjugate (PCV13), Inactivated Poliovirus (IPV), Influenza (Flu), Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR), Varicella (VAR), Hepatitis A, and Rotavirus (RV). Each vaccine has specific age requirements and limitations, such as the age range for administration and any special conditions.

For children from seven through eighteen years old, the vaccines include Influenza (yearly), Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Acellular Pertussis (Tdap), Human Papillomavirus (HPV), and Meningococcal Serogroups A,C,W,Y. The HPV vaccine has specific notes regarding the series of shots required for those with weakened immune systems or those starting the series at age 15 or older.

9.summary:
This page outlines the preventive health services covered under the MEC plan, detailing the benefits, intervals, and specific requirements for each service. Breastfeeding support, supplies, and counseling are provided in conjunction with each birth, with interventions during pregnancy and after birth to support breastfeeding. Cervical cancer screening with cytology is available once every three plan years for women aged 21 to 65. Additionally, cervical cancer screening with a combination of cytology and HPV testing is offered once every five plan years for women aged 30 to 65 with high-risk HPV.

Chlamydia screening is available annually for sexually active women aged 24 and younger, and older women at increased risk. Colorectal cancer screening is provided once every five plan years starting at age 50, with benefits for a colonoscopy if the home test is positive. Contraceptive methods and counseling are offered as prescribed, covering FDA-approved methods and related education.

Dental caries prevention for infants and children up to age 5 is provided annually, with fluoride varnish application and oral fluoride supplementation starting at age 6 months. Depression screening is available annually for adolescents aged 12 to 18 and the general adult population, including pregnant and postpartum women. Diabetes screening is offered annually for adults aged 40 to 70 who are overweight or obese. Fall prevention for older adults is available annually for those aged 65 and older. Folic acid supplementation is prescribed for women planning or capable of pregnancy. Gestational diabetes mellitus screening is provided annually for asymptomatic pregnant women after 24 weeks of gestation.

10.summary:
This page provides a detailed summary of preventive health services covered under the MEC/Preventive Health Services plan. It outlines various benefits, the frequency of coverage, and specific requirements for eligibility. The benefits include Gonorrhea Prophylactic Medication, which is provided as prescribed for all newborns to prevent gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum. Gonorrhea Screening is available once per plan year for sexually active women aged 24 years or younger and older women at increased risk. Healthy Diet and Physical Activity Counseling is offered once per plan year for adults who are overweight or obese with additional cardiovascular disease risk factors.

Hemoglobinopathies Screening is conducted once per plan year for sickle cell disease in newborns. Hepatitis B and C screenings are available once per plan year for non-pregnant adolescents and adults at high risk, with specific provisions for pregnant women and adults born between 1945 and 1965. High Blood Pressure Screening is provided once per plan year for adults aged 18 or older. HIV Preexposure Prophylaxis is prescribed for persons at high risk, while HIV Screening is available once per plan year for adolescents and adults aged 15 to 65 years.

Additional screenings include Hypothyroidism Screening for newborns, Intimate Partner Violence Screening for women of reproductive age, and Lung Cancer Screening for adults aged 55 to 80 years with a significant smoking history. Obesity Screening and Counseling are offered to children, adolescents, and adults with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or higher. Osteoporosis Screening is available for women aged 65 and older, and Phenylketonuria Screening is conducted for newborns.

11.summary:
This page provides a detailed summary of preventive health services covered under the MEC/Preventive Health Services plan. It outlines various benefits, intervals, and specific requirements for each service. Preeclampsia screening is available once per plan year for pregnant women, with blood pressure measurements throughout pregnancy. Rh incompatibility screening is offered during the first pregnancy visit and again at 24-28 weeks' gestation for Rh (D)-negative women. Sexually transmitted infections counseling is provided once per plan year for sexually active adolescents and adults. Skin cancer behavioral counseling is available annually for young adults, adolescents, children, and parents of young children to minimize ultraviolet radiation exposure.

Statin preventive medication is prescribed for adults with a history of cardiovascular disease or risk factors. Syphilis screening is conducted annually for non-pregnant persons at increased risk and all pregnant women. Tobacco use counseling and interventions are offered twice per plan year for adults and pregnant women, including behavioral interventions and FDA-approved pharmacotherapy. Tuberculosis screening is available annually for latent infection in at-risk populations. Vision screening is provided once every two plan years for children aged 3 to 5. Well-woman visits are available annually for women under 65, and well-child visits are offered annually for children, with one visit recommended for children under three.

The page emphasizes the importance of preventive services and outlines specific criteria for eligibility and frequency of each service. It provides a structured overview of the preventive measures covered, ensuring that members are informed about the available health services and their requirements.

13.summary: This page provides a detailed summary of benefits under the MEC/Preventive Health Services plan, focusing on immunizations for adults aged nineteen years or older. The table lists various vaccines, including Influenza inactivated, Influenza recombinant, and Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis, among others. Each vaccine is accompanied by specific age requirements and limitations, such as the Influenza inactivated vaccine being available annually for individuals aged 19 to 65 years. The Tdap vaccine is recommended for ages 19 to 65, with a booster every 10 years. The page also includes a section on exclusions, detailing specific services and conditions not covered by the plan. These exclusions include routine foot care, dental procedures, and any medical service not explicitly provided in the plan document. Additionally, claims related to injury or illness arising out of employment or covered by a Worker's Compensation policy are excluded. The page emphasizes that certain medical services, treatments, or procedures are not covered unless specifically authorized as medically necessary.

14.summary:
This page outlines the exclusions and limitations associated with the MEC/Preventive Health Services plan. It lists specific conditions and services that are not covered under the plan. These include claims arising from acts of war, services not medically necessary, and treatments related to fertility or infertility. Additionally, claims for cosmetic surgery, experimental treatments, and services primarily educational in nature are excluded. The document also specifies that claims related to illegal acts, self-inflicted injuries, and certain travel-related expenses are not covered. 

The exclusions extend to various medical services such as chiropractic care, acupuncture, and alternative medicine. Claims for durable medical equipment, hospice care, and residential facilities not licensed for healthcare are also excluded. The plan does not cover organ transplants, genetic testing, or any claims not explicitly covered in the schedule of benefits. Furthermore, the document clarifies that exclusions are meant to provide clarity and should not be interpreted as evidence of coverage for any service not listed.

15.summary:
This page outlines the individual and family dental plans offered by GoodHealth Distribution Partners, utilizing the MaximumCare PPO networks. Three plans are available: Dental 1500, Dental 3000, and Dental 5000, each with different annual maximums of $1,500, $3,000, and $5,000 per person, respectively. The plans include a $50 annual deductible for basic and major services per person and $150 per family, with no deductible for preventative services. 

Preventive care is covered at 100% with no waiting period, including routine exams, cleanings, bitewing X-rays, and fluoride treatments for children under 16. Basic care is covered at 80% with no waiting period, covering services like full mouth X-rays, sealants, space maintainers, restorative amalgams, and simple extractions. Major care is covered at 50% with a 12-month waiting period, including onlays, oral surgery, crowns, endodontics, periodontics, dentures, bridges, complex extractions, and anesthesia. 

The plan follows the 'Carve Out' Coordination of Benefits method, which calculates the normal plan benefits and reduces them by the amount paid by the primary plan. Products are not available in certain states, including MA, MD, ME, NH, OR, VT, and WA.

16.summary:
This page outlines the limitations and exclusions applicable to the GoodHealth Dental Plan. It specifies that no benefits are payable for services not included in the Schedule of Covered Procedures. Services started or appliances installed before the effective or termination date are not covered, except as noted in the certificate. Procedures deemed unnecessary or experimental, as well as those not offering a favorable prognosis, are excluded. Cosmetic procedures not recognized by the American Dental Association are also not covered unless listed in the Schedule of Covered Procedures.

The document further excludes coverage for appliances or procedures related to changes in vertical dimension, splinting, and bite analysis. Replacement of bridges and dentures is not covered if they exceed the age limits specified in the Schedule of Covered Procedures. Orthodontic services and treatments for temporomandibular joint dysfunction are excluded unless specifically listed as covered. Additional exclusions include charges for precision attachments, athletic mouth guards, and various professional services such as myofunctional therapy and treatment for malignancies.

The plan also excludes coverage for prescription drugs, premedication, pharmaceuticals, or analgesia. These limitations ensure that only specified procedures and services are eligible for coverage, emphasizing the importance of consulting the Schedule of Covered Procedures for detailed coverage information.

20.summary:
This page introduces a modern approach to vision care, highlighting the limitations of traditional vision insurance, which has not evolved in over 20 years. It points out that only 50% of employees use their vision insurance, with high costs averaging $230 per pair of glasses, and a poor experience reflected by a -8 NPS score. The new vision care solution offers a digital-first platform that replaces traditional insurance, aiming to keep costs low and improve satisfaction. 

The page details an eyewear marketplace that eliminates markups, providing access for all with 100% usage. It offers over 1,500 designer frames and sunglasses at an average cost of $42 per pair. The platform promises a great experience with a +72 NPS, utilizing AI technology for virtual try-ons to find the perfect eyewear. 

Additional benefits include improved access to eye exams, with in-person exams available at no cost through a network of over 99,000 providers. RX renewals are available on demand, allowing employees to get the care they need through simple online prescription renewals. The service is trusted and vetted, partnering with innovative organizations and recognized by top publications. Note that this plan is only available when bundled with one of three dental plans: 1500 Plan, 3000 Plan, or 5000 Plan.

19.summary:
This page outlines the limitations and exclusions related to the Coordination of Benefits (COB) provision for the GoodHealth Insurance Plan. It details the order of benefit payments when a person is covered by more than one plan. The hierarchy for payment begins with a plan covering a person as a non-dependent, followed by plans covering them as a dependent. Specific rules are provided for dependent children with separated or divorced parents, including the order of plans based on custody and court orders. Joint custody scenarios are also addressed, specifying the application of rules when custody details are not clear.

The document further explains the rights related to receiving and releasing necessary information for COB, emphasizing that consent is not required for obtaining such information. It also covers the right to make payments to another plan and the right to recovery, which allows the plan to reclaim overpayments. An appeal process is described for cases where claims are denied, requiring a written appeal within 60 days of denial. The appeal decision will be communicated within 15 days, with provisions for additional time if needed.

Contact information for submitting appeals is provided, directing correspondence to the Merchants Benefit Administration, Attn: Appeals Department, in Scottsdale, AZ. The page concludes with a note encouraging individuals to refer to the plan document if they are dissatisfied with the appeal response.

18.summary:
This page outlines the limitations and exclusions associated with the GoodHealth Dental Plan. It begins by discussing alternate benefits, noting that when multiple services can address a dental problem, the plan will cover the least costly option. The plan will not cover the excess amount if a more expensive procedure is chosen. Specific details are provided for resin fillings on posterior teeth, which will be paid at the rate for amalgam fillings. The document also addresses the missing tooth clause, stating that no benefits will be paid for teeth missing before the effective date of coverage. However, exceptions are made for replacements of teeth extracted while covered under the group policy, with certain restrictions. The missing teeth limitation can be waived after five continuous years of coverage if it involves replacing an unserviceable prosthesis.

The page also includes a timely filing limit, requiring claims to be submitted within 12 months from the date of service. Coordination of Benefits (COB) is explained, indicating that when a person has coverage under more than one plan, benefits will be coordinated using the 'Carve Out' method. The order of benefit determination is outlined, specifying how benefits are paid when multiple plans are involved. This section ensures clarity on how benefits are coordinated to avoid overpayment or duplication of coverage.

17.summary:
This page outlines the limitations and exclusions applicable to the GoodHealth Dental Plan. It specifies that dental diseases, defects, or injuries caused by acts of war, terrorism, or criminal activities are not covered. Additionally, dental treatments not approved by the American Dental Association or those considered experimental are excluded. Services available under Worker’s Compensation or similar laws are not covered, and treatments performed outside the United States are limited to a maximum of $100 per plan year, except for emergency treatments.

The document details restrictions on the initial placement of dentures and bridges, requiring that they replace a natural tooth extracted while insured. It also excludes full-mouth reconstruction services and treatments for congenital or developmental malformations, except within 31 days of a child's birth. Dental care provided by government facilities is not covered unless there is a legal obligation to pay.

Other exclusions include dental services performed in hospitals, services covered under existing medical plans, charges exceeding reasonable amounts, fees for missed appointments, and nitrous sedation. These limitations ensure that only specific dental services are eligible for coverage under the plan.

BRCA Risk Assessment and Genetic Counseling/Testing

Women with positive screening results should receive genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, BRCA testing.

presentation.content:
# Presentation Plan for Good Health Insurance

## Deck ID: FEN_GDH
## Deck Title: Good Health

### Cover (1 slide)
- **Plan Name:** Good Health
- **Tagline:** "Empowering Your Health Journey with Accessible and Affordable Care"

### Plan Overview (1 slide)
- **Target Audience:** Individuals and Families
- **Offerings:** Healthcare services focusing on wellness, telemedicine, and prescription coverage.
- **Key Benefits:** Accessibility, affordability, and personal impact through comprehensive support services.

### Core Plan Elements (3 slides)
- **Coverage Areas:**
  - Physician services, hospitalization, virtual visits.
- **Plan Structure:**
  - Tiered options with varying co-pays and visit limits.
- **Eligibility:**
  - Focus on affordability for individuals and families.

### Common Service Features (3 slides)
- **Provider Networks:**
  - Extensive networks for in-network services.
- **Claims Management:**
  - Efficient processing and support.
- **Support Tools:**
  - Dashboards, wellness programs, and advocacy services.

### Plan Tiers Breakdown (12 slides)

#### GHDP-W - Good Health Wellness Plan
- **Benefits:**
  - Wellness Exam: 1 visit/year, $25 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Telemedicine: No consult fee, no maximum.
  - Discount Prescriptions: Available through BestChoice RX.
  - Support Services: 24/7 access via Kindly Human.

#### GHDP-1 - Good Health 1 Plan
- **Benefits:**
  - Primary Care: 3 visits/year, $25 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Specialist/Urgent Care: 1 visit/year, $50 co-pay, $300 max/visit.
  - In-Patient Hospitalization: $1,000/day, $5,000/year max.
  - Telemedicine: No consult fee, no maximum.
  - Advocacy: Hospital Bill Reducer.

#### GHDP-2 - Good Health 2 Plan
- **Benefits:**
  - Primary Care: 4 visits/year, $25 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Specialist/Urgent Care: 2 visits/year, $50 co-pay, $300 max/visit.
  - In-Patient Hospitalization: $1,000/day, $10,000/year max.
  - Telemedicine: No consult fee, no maximum.
  - Prescription Terms: Preventive and acute prescriptions with formulary.

#### GHDP-3 - Good Health 3 Plan
- **Benefits:**
  - Primary Care: 4 visits/year, $25 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Specialist/Urgent Care: 4 visits/year, $50 co-pay, $300 max/visit.
  - In-Patient Hospitalization: $1,000/day, $15,000/year max.
  - Telemedicine: No consult fee, no maximum.
  - Prescription Coverage: Includes preventive and acute prescriptions.

#### GHDP-4 - Good Health 4 Plan
- **Benefits:**
  - Wellness Exam: 1 visit/year, $25 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Primary Care: 4 visits/year, $50 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Specialist/Urgent Care: 4 visits/year, $75 co-pay, $300 max/visit.
  - In-Patient Hospitalization: $1,000/day, $10,000/year max.
  - Telemedicine: No consult fee, no maximum.

#### GHDP-5 - Good Health 5 Plan
- **Benefits:**
  - Wellness Exam: 1 visit/year, $25 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Primary Care: 5 visits/year, $50 co-pay, $150 max/visit.
  - Specialist/Urgent Care: 5 visits/year, $75 co-pay, $300 max/visit.
  - In-Patient Hospitalization: $1,500/day, $15,000/year max.
  - Telemedicine: No consult fee, no maximum.

### Comparison Slides (Markdown Table)

```markdown
| Feature/Benefit                  | GHDP-W | GHDP-1 | GHDP-2 | GHDP-3 | GHDP-4 | GHDP-5 |
|----------------------------------|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|
| Wellness Exam                    | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      |
| Primary Care Visits              | -      | 3      | 4      | 4      | 4      | 5      |
| Specialist/Urgent Care Visits    | -      | 1      | 2      | 4      | 4      | 5      |
| In-Patient Hospitalization       | -      | $5,000 | $10,000| $15,000| $10,000| $15,000|
| Telemedicine                     | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      |
| Prescription Coverage            | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      | ✔      |
```

### Limitations and Exclusions (2 slides)
- **Exclusions:**
  - Pre-existing conditions, waiting periods, prescription limitations.
- **Specific Limitations:**
  - 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits, in-network provider requirements.

### Key Takeaways and Action Steps (1 slide)
- **Flexibility and Balance:**
  - Plans offer a balance between cost and coverage.
- **Next Steps:**
  - Enrollment details and support contact information.

### Thank You (1 slide)
- **Message:** "Thank you for considering Good Health. Your journey to better health starts here."

script.content:
---- Cover ----

Hello, everyone! Thank you for joining today's session on the Good Health Insurance Plan. We'll walk through the plan's features and benefits that empower your members health with financial peace of mind. Let's get started!

---- Plan Overview ----

Understanding the details and benefits of the Good Health Insurance Plan

is about empowering your health journey with accessible and affordable care through Good Health.

The plan offers healthcare services focusing on wellness, telemedicine, and prescription coverage.

It emphasizes accessibility, affordability, and personal impact through extensive support services.

---- Key Features and Benefits ----

Let's explore the key features and benefits of this plan.

The plan ensures accessibility to essential health services.

Affordability is a key focus, making healthcare more reachable.

It offers extensive support services, which vary by plan.

Prescription coverage is provided through BestChoice RX.

---- Cost Management Tools ----

Now, let's discuss the cost management tools available with this plan.

The Hospital Bill Reducer, or HBR, is a significant tool.

Efficient Claims Management System helps streamline processes.

Support tools are available for wellness and advocacy.

---- How Hospital Bill Reducer Works ----

Here's how the Hospital Bill Reducer works.

First, you enroll through Good Health.

Next, submit hospital bills for review.

The advocacy team then negotiates on your behalf.

You will receive a reduced bill statement through HBR.

Finally, pay the reduced amount.

---- Preventive Care and Wellness ----

Preventive care and wellness are integral parts of the plan.

Wellness Exam Services are available to members.

Preventive Health Programs are designed to keep you healthy.

Kindly Human provides twenty-four seven support for everyday challenges.

---- Telehealth Services ----

Telehealth services offer several advantages.

There is no consult fee for telehealth services.

Members have unlimited access to telehealth.

Care is convenient and accessible.

Telehealth services are available twenty-four seven.

---- Advocacy and Support Services ----

Advocacy and support services are crucial components.

The plan offers extensive healthcare advocacy.

Hospital Bill Reducer assistance is available.

Prescription assistance options are provided.

Twenty-four seven support is available through Kindly Human.

---- Plan Tier 1 (One of Two) ----

Let's examine our first plan tier, the Good Health Wellness Plan.

The Wellness Exam includes one visit per year with a twenty-five dollar co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit.

Telemedicine services have no consult fee and no maximum.

Discount prescriptions are available through BestChoice RX.

---- Plan Tier 1 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our first plan tier.

Support services offer twenty-four seven access via Kindly Human.

There is a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits.

---- Plan Tier 2 (One of Two) ----

Now, let's look at our second plan tier, the Good Health 1 Plan.

Primary Care includes three visits per year with a twenty-five dollar co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit.

Specialist or Urgent Care includes one visit per year with a fifty dollar co-pay and a three hundred dollar maximum per visit.

In-Patient Hospitalization is covered at one thousand dollars per day with a five thousand dollar yearly maximum.

---- Plan Tier 2 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our second plan tier.

Telemedicine services have no consult fee and no maximum.

Advocacy services include the Hospital Bill Reducer.

---- Plan Tier 3 (One of Two) ----

Let's explore the Good Health 2 Plan.

Primary Care includes four visits per year with a twenty-five dollar co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit.

Specialist or Urgent Care includes two visits per year with a fifty dollar co-pay and a three hundred dollar maximum per visit.

In-Patient Hospitalization is covered at one thousand dollars per day with a ten thousand dollar yearly maximum.

---- Plan Tier 3 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with the Good Health 2 Plan.

Telemedicine services have no consult fee and no maximum.

Prescription terms include preventive and acute prescriptions with a formulary.

---- Plan Tier 4 (One of Two) ----

Now, let's examine the Good Health 3 Plan.

Primary Care includes four visits per year with a twenty-five dollar co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit.

Specialist or Urgent Care includes four visits per year with a fifty dollar co-pay and a three hundred dollar maximum per visit.

In-Patient Hospitalization is covered at one thousand dollars per day with a fifteen thousand dollar yearly maximum.

---- Plan Tier 4 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with the Good Health 3 Plan.

Telemedicine services have no consult fee and no maximum.

Prescription coverage includes preventive and acute prescriptions.

---- Plan Tier 5 (One of Two) ----

Telemedicine services have no consult fee and no maximum.

Each plan offers unique benefits tailored to different needs.

Coordination of Benefits outlines the order of benefit payments, rights to information, and the appeal process.

There is a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits.

Network requirements include in-network provider restrictions.
